abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was unsatisfactory,
            sustainability unlikely, and institutional development
            impacts negligible. Although overall, the bank performance
            is rated as satisfactory, the performance by the borrower is
            assessed as highly unsatisfactory, given the loss of
            government commitment by subsequent administrations,
            aggravated by difficulties in obtaining counterpart funds,
            and the often politically motivated appointments of key
            managers. Lessons address: 1) beneficiary participation as
            an essential feature in the identification, planning, and
            implementation process, to ensure the financing of
            sustainable investments; 2) the complex nature of rural
            development projects (which few developing countries have
            managerial capacities for integrated solutions), suggests
            simplified demand driven models as most likely to succeed;
            3) the continuing ownership of project objectives, and
            strategies by stakeholders, as a prerequisite for a
            project's success; 4) the erroneous assumption that
            surplus labor, through community maintenance arrangements
            for rural roads, and infrastructure works will assure
            success, should be replaced by identifying viable incentives
            to gain stakeholders' participation; 5) reliability on
            appropriate indicators, agreed during appraisal for
            effective monitoring of project impacts, should be in place,
            to evaluate specific issues, i.e., technology adoption, and
            stakeholder commitment, designed to assist problem solving,
            and project impact assessment; and, 6) substantial risks due
            to political or economic instability, identified at
            appraisal as endangering the project's primary
            objective, could be mitigated by shortening the
            implementation period, and, project design should seek to
            insulate project management from political interference, to
            avoid unnecessary management, and staff turnover.

5079142.trustfund:
TF023410-SIDA CTF FOR ENVIRONMENT,TF040404-ECUADOR:  RURAL DEVELOPMENT:
            LOOKING AHEAD,TF023412-SIDA CTF (POPULAR PARTICIPATION II)
5079142.majtheme: Trade and integration,Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The project was conceived as the first
            phase of a longer-term effort to reduce poverty and promote
            socio-economic development in selected rural areas. Its main
            components are to: (a) complete and rehabilitate six
            irrigation schemes, two flood control schemes and 43
            existing water courses, which will irrigate an incremental
            area of about 26,000 ha; (b) improve adaptive research and
            extension services for validation and transfer of
            technology, aimed at increasing investment by small farmers;
            (c) promote forestation and better conservation of natural
            resources; (d) improve marketing facilities and foster small
            rural enterprises at the local and community level; (e)
            establish a community development fund to help finance small
            local projects; (f) improve approximately 700 km of existing
            feeder roads and construct about 100 km new rural roads; (g)
            construct small water reservoirs to supply water for
            domestic use to about 22,000 people; (h) regularize land
            tenure in approximately 110,000 ha and issue about 10,000
            new land titles; (i) establish a unit to monitor the
            environmental impact of the project; and (j) implement a
            comprehensive institutional development program for the
            Ministry of Social Welfare.
